segments.text: I'll put it where it goes later and says you'll have to come on.
He backed up in the front of.

of scarborough's you know it steps up at that time it it's had a step up of about six or eight inches before you went into the door down to the sidewalk which was lower which was much slower and um it was a very rough sidewalk there it wasn't smooth like it is like it was later on they did great improvement there but it was rough
In other words, it was part rock and part cement and just anything to keep you off of the mud.
That's really what it was.
And he sat down and he took these shoes off.
And he put them over his shoulder and James Ely took his off.
He said, these shoes are killing me.
He said, if we're going to walk to that wagon yard, he said, these shoes are killing me.
Well, that was a sin in this community for years.
Papa Blackton told it about the two boys sitting down pulling their shoes off.
My shoes are killing me.
I'm going to the wagon yard.
And that was a sin.
That was a colloquialism that no one else but knew why they'd say that.
But that really happened.
And you can just think of an old country boy coming to town
never wearing any shoes at all, and buying a pair of patent leather shoes on a hot summer day in Texas and walking on pavement.
It wasn't pavement, but concrete.
You can understand why he said, I'm taking these things off.
They're just killing me.
Oh, yeah.
That's great.
Now, to me, that's things that really happen.
And then
Well, it is a fact that our children today know more than we do because they've had a better opportunity.
Come right in!
That we have had to learn, but they know less.
How are you, sweetheart?
They know less about human relations to one another.
Yeah, they've been robbed of that.
They've been robbed of it.
Yeah, that's true.
They haven't been brought up with that closeness to one another like we were.
I've had so many people ask me, well, why are you so protective of Lyndon?
I said, for the simple reason I was the oldest girl in the Johnson family of any of the grandchildren.
Tom Martin was the oldest boy, and he was 12 years older than I.
There was not too much feeling there.
But I was taught to guard over every one of my little cousins and to take care of them.
And I said, I'd slip off and go get Leonard, because he was always ready to go.
And always ready to do.
And I was always ready to help and to do.
And honest to goodness, that's very true.
And we were so much alike in that drive to get going and do things.
And that's the reason that we were always so close and did so many things together.
OK.
